Soil_Colour.desc: Simple description of the colour of the soil. This field is interpreted from the Soil Munsell Colour

Compaction.desc: The degree to which the sediment particles adhere to one another and require force to be separated. Follow this procedure to determine soil compaction/consistence. Take a ped (an aggregate of soil) from the soil horizon. If the soil is very dry, moisten the face of the profile with a water bottle first. Holding the ped between your thumb and forefinger, gently squeeze it until it “pops” or falls apart. Loose soil will not need to be squeezed, while soft soil will fall apart immediately. Slightly hard soil takes some pressure, while hard soil takes a lot of pressure. Very hard soil can only be broken apart along its structure using a digging tool, and cemented soil cannot be broken apart along its structure at all.

Soil_Texture_Actual.desc: Proportions of different grain sizes within the deposit, eg if there is more sand to silt it should be described as a 'silty sand'.

Structure.desc: “The arrangement of primary soil particles into compound particles or aggregates.

opts.opt: Single Grain Sediment that is broken into individual particles that do not stick together. Typically accompanies loose consistence in sandy sediments.
Massive Sediments that have no visible structure, are hard to break apart, and appear in very large clods.
Laminated Distinct bands of varying sediment texture (e.g. silts, medium sands, clays) that usually deposit at non-horizontal angles. Common in canals, reservoirs, and wells.
Platy Thin, flat plates of soil that lie horizontally. Usually found in compacted soil.
Granular Resembles cookie crumbs and is usually less than 0.5 cm in diameter. Commonly found in surface horizons where roots have been growing.
Blocky Irregular blocks that are usually 1.5 to 5.0 cm in diameter.
Prismatic Vertical columns of soil typically more than 5 cm long. Usually found in lower soil horizons.
Columnar Vertical columns of soil that have a white rounded salt 'cap' at the top. They occur very commonly in arid climates.

Structure_Modifiers.desc: Describe the degree to which the structure is developed. Also describe in the notes if the ped size is large, medium, or fine.

opts.opt: None There is no apparent structure.
Weak Some structure is apparent, but it is inconsistent within the horizon.
Moderate Structure is moderately developed throughout the horizon.
Strong Structure is well-developed throughout the horizon.

Sorting.desc: Assessment of the frequency with which particles of the same size occur.

opts.opt: Very poorly sorted Particles are very different sizes and very unevenly distributed.
Poorly sorted Particles are different sizes and unevenly distributed.
Moderately sorted Particles are mostly the same size and evenly distributed, but there are some larger particles.
Well sorted Particles are roughly the same size and evenly distributed.

Inclusions_Gravel_Fraction.desc: Include amounts and qualities; i.e. 'Minor CaCO3 filaments' or 'Minor cultural material present'.

Upper_Boundary.desc: Describe the overall way in which the upper boundary of the horizon contacts the one above it. If a secondary boundary type applies, describe it in the comments.

opts.opt: Merging Horizon merges gradually with the one above it.
Clear Boundary is clearly defined but not sharp.
Sharp/Straight Boundary is clearly defined and sharp.
Smooth Boundary is apparent but not clearly defined.
Continuous Boundary is continuous across the exposed profile, but takes more than one form.
Discontinuous Boundary is discontinuous across the exposed profile, and takes more than one form.

Lower_Boundary.desc: Describe the overall way in which the lower boundary of the horizon contacts the one above it. If a secondary boundary type applies, describe it in the comments.

opts.opt: Merging Horizon merges gradually with the one above it.
Clear Boundary is clearly defined but not sharp.
Sharp/Straight Boundary is clearly defined and sharp.
Smooth Boundary is apparent but not clearly defined.
Continuous Boundary is continuous across the exposed profile, but takes more than one form.
Discontinuous Boundary is discontinuous across the exposed profile, and takes more than one form.

Artefact_Group_ID.desc: Unique number or code for the artefact group.
